com.moniuliuma.android.device

Class UHFReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.moniuliuma.android.device.UHFReader

  • public class UHFReader
extends java.lang.Object
    The command set provides many programming commands for controlling ISO 18000-6C/6B compatible 40505W-M

    RFID module. The host can configure the 40505W-M RFID module for operation and tag protocol operations can be issued.

    The host initiates transactions with ISO 18000-6C/6B tags or tag populations by executing ISO 18000-6C/6B

    tag-protocol operations. The command set exposes direct access to the following ISO 18000-6C/6B tag-protocol

    operations:
    Inventory
    • Read Write Kill (only for ISO 18000-6C tag) Lock (only for ISO 18000-6C tag)
    After inventory operation, first the host should send a select operation in case there are several tags found, and then perform the tag-protocol operation.

    The 40505W-M MAC firmware provides some response packets for presenting tag-protocol operation response data to the host. Tag-protocol operation results include EPC values returned by the Inventory operation, read data returned by the Read operation, and operation status returned by the Write, Kill, and Lock operations.

    • Method Detail

      • sendCMD

        public boolean sendCMD(byte[] cmd)
        Command Packet Format
        Header Type Command PL(MSB) PL(LSB) Parameter Checksum End

          Header: 0xBB Type: 0x00 Command ID: 0x07 like Constants PL: 0x0001(The Data Length is byte number over the Parameters field.) Parameter: 0x01 Checksum: 0x09 (The Checksum is CRC-16 calculated over the Type field to the Parameters field. and only takes the sum and the lowest byte (LSB).) End: 0x7E
        Type
          0x00 Command: host send to 40505W-M Module 0x01 Response: from 40505W-M response to host 0x02 notify: from 40505W-M response to host

        0x00 Example: Get Hardware version command

        0xBB 00 03 00 01 00 04 7E
        Response Format Fields/b>
        0x01 Example: Hardware version

        Header Type Command PL(MSB) PL(LSB) (Data type ID) Data Checksum End

        The Data Length is byte number over the Response ID field to the Returned Data field.


        0x02 notify Example: Inventory command notify

        Header Type Command PL(MSB) PL(LSB) RSSI PC(MSB) PC(LSB) EPC(MSB) EPC(LSB) CRC(MSB) CRC(LSB) Checksum End

        BB 02 22 00 11 C9 34 00 30 75 1F EB 70 5C 59 04 E3 D5 0D 70 3A 76 EF 7E

          Type: 0x02 Command: 0x22like Constants PL: 0x0011 RSSI: 0xC9 PC: 0x3400 EPC: 0x30751FEB705C5904E3D50D70 CRC : 0x3A76 Checksum: 0xEF End 0x7E

      • readResponse

        public int readResponse(byte[] buffer,
                        int byteOffset,
                        int byteCount)
        Reads up len bytes of data from the input stream into an arryay of bytes. The length of the response packet is variable. In response packet, italic text is applied to the value in the both Byte Offset and Name columns of the common fields to indicate they are Response Data. If the incorrect command packet was sent, then reply nothing to host.
        Parameters:
        buffer - the buffer into which the data is read.
        byteOffset - the start offset in array b at which the data is written.
        byteCount - the maximum number of bytes to read.
        Returns:
        the total number of bytes read into the buffer, or -1 if there is no more data because the end of the stream has been reached.return -2,if some other I/O error occurs.return -1,if the input stream is null.

      • setModemParam

        public boolean setModemParam(int mixer_g,
                             int if_g,
                             int trd)
        Set RFID module’s receiver demodulator parameters. The demodulator parameters are Mixer gain, intermediate frequency amplifier IF AMP gain and signal demodulation threshold The mixer is one of: *
        Type Mixer_G(dB)
        0x00 0
        0x01 3
        0x02 6
        0x03 9
        0x04 12
        0x05 15
        0x06 16
        Type IF_G(dB)
        0x00 12
        0x01 18
        0x02 21
        0x03 24
        0x04 27
        0x05 30
        0x06 36
        0x07 40
        Parameters:
        mixer_g - Miller Value
        if_g - IF AMP Value
        trd - RSSI default 624.The smaller the signal demodulation threshold is, the lower the RSSI returned to the tag can be demodulated, but the more unstable it is, the lower the demodulation value is, the higher the threshold value is, the greater the RSSI of the signal returned to the tag is, the closer the distance is, the more stable the signal is. 0x01B0 is the recommended minimum
        Returns:
        true if success, If failed, return false.

      • getModemParam

        public byte[] getModemParam()
        Get RFID module’s receiver demodulator parameters.
        Returns:
        4 bytes arary.byte[0] is mixer type; byte[1] is IF AMP type;byte[2] is RSSI hight 8 bit,byte[3] is RSSI low 8 bit;null if failed.
        See Also:
        setModemParam(int, int, int)

      • setFrequency

        public int setFrequency(int startFrequency)
        Configures the RFID module’s frequency within region of operation and gets the reflected power or the RSSI value of the channel.
        Parameters:
        startFrequency - The frequency is transmitted in KHz that means 920125 means920.125MHz.For china 900MHz Channel Index = (startFrequency - 920125) / 250

        Region TypeIF_G(dB)
        CHN CH_Index = (startFrequency-920.125M)/0.25M
        US CH_Index = (startFrequency-902.25M)/0.5M
        EUR CH_Index = (startFrequency-865.1M)/0.2M
        KOREA CH_Index = (startFrequency-917.1M)/0.2M
        Returns:
        0 if success, -1 if it's failed

      • getFrequency

        public int getFrequency()
        Get the RFID module’s frequency.
        Returns:
        Channel Index. For china frequency Freq_CH = CH_Index * 0.25M + 920.125M
        Region TypeIF_G(dB)
        CHN Freq_CH = CH_Index * 0.25M + 920.125M
        US Freq_CH = CH_Index * 0.5M + 902.25M
        EUR Freq_CH = CH_Index * 0.2M + 865.1M
        KOREA Freq_CH = CH_Index * 0.2M + 917.1M

      • setFHSS

        public boolean setFHSS(int operation)
        Configures the operation of RFID module’s physical antenna port.

        Parameters:
        operation - The state of FHSS or LBT operation for the physical transmit antenna.

        If the Operation value = 0x00, perform the tag access operation with the first frequency of channel list.

          0x00 = disabled 0x01 = enabled
        Returns:
        true if success, false if it's failed.

      • setSelectMode

        public int setSelectMode(byte mode)
        If the Select parameter has been set and the instruction is executed, the Select mode can be set. For example, if you want to cancel the Select directive
        Parameters:
        mode - set the select mode. Valid values are:
          All operations on the tag, Select instructions are sent in advance to select a specific tag.Constants.INVENTORY_MODE0 Select instructions are not sent before tag operations are performed Constants.INVENTORY_MODE1 Send Select instructions only before tag operations other than polling Inventory,es.Read, Write, Lock, Kill operation TAG before must execute SelectConstants.INVENTORY_MODE2

      • selectEpc

        public int selectEpc(byte[] epc)
        To communicate with one tag the host must isolate one of the found tags. The host needs to send always all EPC bytes to the RFID module regardless how long the EPC mask is specified.
        Parameters:
        epc - EPC mask data
        Returns:
        0 if success, other if failed;

      • unSelect

        public int unSelect()

      • setSelectPara

        public int setSelectPara(byte target,
                         byte action,
                         byte memBank,
                         int pointer,
                         byte maskLen,
                         boolean truncated,
                         byte[] mask)
        Set the Select parameter and set the Select mode to 0x02 at the same time. The Select command is sent before the label is removed from polling. In multi label In the case of signing, we can only poll and read and write specific tags according to the Select parameter
        Parameters:
        target -
        action -
        memBank - The memory bank in which to write.Valid values are:

          0x00 Reserved memory 0x01 EPC memory 0x02 TID memory 0x03 User memory
        pointer - starts from the EPC storage bit
        maskLen - the mask data length(es. 0x60(6 word==96bits))
        truncated - false is Disable truncation,true is Enable truncation
        mask - Select TAG Mask data.When the length of Select Mask is greater than 80 bits (5 words), the Select command is sent to all the tags in the field area to be set as Inventoried Flag For A, SL Flag is the state of ~SL, and then the operation is performed according to the selected Action. When Select Mask length is less than 80 bits (5 words) The label state is not set in advance by Select instruction to Inventoried Flag, and SL Flag is ~SL state in A.
        Returns:
        0 if success. other if failed.

      • readFrom6C

        public byte[] readFrom6C(int memBank,
                         int startAddr,
                         int length,
                         byte[] accessPassword,
                         byte[] PC,
                         byte[] EPC)
        A read operation can be used to read one or more 16-bit words from any of a tag’s memory banks. Reads may only be performed on 16-bit word boundaries and for multiples of 16-bit words. If one or more of the memory words specified by the Address/Length combination do not exist or are read-locked, the read from the tag fails and this failure is reported through the operation response packet. The response data length of this command is different between USB and UART interface.
        Parameters:
        memBank - The memory bank in which to write.Valid values are:

          0x00 Reserved memory 0x01 EPC memory 0x02 TID memory 0x03 User memory
        startAddr - The address of the first 16-bit word, where zero is the first 16-bit word in the memory bank, to read from the specified memory bank.
        length - Read tag data area address length DL
        accessPassword - The access password for the tags. A value of zero indicates no access password.
        PC - Response PC buffer 2 bytes
        EPC - Response EPC buffer
        Returns:
        Tag data information in words.When the value of Tag Data Length field is > 1, this field is valid, if retuen length == 1, first byte is error code. return null if failed.

      • writeTo6C

        public int writeTo6C(byte[] password,
                     int memBank,
                     int startAddr,
                     int dataLen,
                     byte[] data,
                     byte[] PC,
                     byte[] EPC)
        Tags implemented BlockWrite (optional command in the ISO 18000-6C standard) allow an interrogator to write multiple words in tag’s memory (reserved, EPC, TID or user memory bank) using a single command. Command/Response and user scenario of BlockWrite are the same as Write command. The data length of this command is not fixed value. Maybe for differential USB development platform, the application needs to send fixed size of packet. For this command, the application can pad zero value added to end of Mask Data field to force this packet to stuff 63 bytes length.
        Parameters:
        password - The access password for the tags. A value of zero indicates no access password.
        memBank - The memory bank in which to write.Valid values are:

          0x00 Reserved memory 0x01 EPC memory 0x02 TID memory 0x03 User memory
        startAddr - The address of the first 16-bit word, where zero is the first 16-bit word in the memory bank, to write in the specified memory bank.
        dataLen - The number of 16-bit words to be written.
        data - The data (16-bits words) to be written to the tag’s specified memory bank. When the value of Tag Data Length field is >= 1, this field is valid. Byte offset n = 2 * value of Tag Data Length field + 8
        PC - Response PC buffer 2 bytes
        EPC - Response EPC buffer
        Returns:
        0 if success, other if failed. example:
          Access Password: 0x0000FFFF memBank: 0x03 startAddr: 0x0000 dataLen: 0x0002 data: 0x12345678 The data length DT of the write tag data storage should be no more than 32 word, that is, 64Byte bytes /512Bit bits.

      • lock6CwithPayload

        public int lock6CwithPayload(byte[] password,
                             int payload,
                             byte[] PC,
                             byte[] EPC)
        A lock operation allows a host to execute a tag lock (setting a tag’s access permissions) for all tags of interest.For a single tag, lock the Lock or unlock the data storage area of the Unlock tag. The Select parameter should be set prior to this instruction for selection Locking the Lock operation with the specified tag
        Parameters:
        password - The access password for the tags.
        payload -
        PC - Response PC buffer 2 bytes
        EPC - Response EPC buffer
        Returns:
        0 if success, other number if failed:

          other error -1 password param length errorERROR_CODE_ACCESS_FAIL TAG missing Constants.FAIL_LOCK_ERROR_CODE access password errorConstants.FAIL_ACCESS_PWD_ERROR

        Parameters:

          0x00 Kill Password in Reserved memory bank 0x01 Access Password in Reserved memory bank 0x02 EPC memory bank 0x03 TID memory bank 0x04 User memory bank
        lockType - Lock actions..Valid values are:

        Returns:

      • lock6C

        public int lock6C(byte[] password,
                  int memSpace,
                  int lockType,
                  byte[] PC,
                  byte[] EPC)
        A tag-permission command (tag lock) allows the host to set the access permissions of a tag. These include the following:

        Set whether or not an access password is required to write to the EPC, TID, or user memory banks.
        • Set whether or not the above memory-write permission is permanently set. Once the memory-write permission has been permanently set, attempts to change the permission or turn off the permanent setting fail. Set a memory bank to be read-only. Set whether or not the individual passwords (i.e. access and kill) may be accessed (i.e. read and written) and, if they are accessible, whether or not an access password is required to read the individual passwords (i.e. access and kill). Set whether or not the above password-access permission is permanently set. Once the password-access permission has been permanently set, attempts to change the permission or turn off the permanent setting fail. Set the individual passwords to be inaccessible (i.e. unable to be read or written).
        For a tag, there are five access permissions that may be set: access permissions for the EPC, TID, and user memory banks and access permissions for the access and kill passwords.

        There are several scenarios in which attempting to set a tag’s access permissions may fail:

        Attempting to change the access permission for a non-existent memory bank or password. Attempting to change an access permission that has been previously set as permanent. Attempting to change the permanent status of an access permission that has been previously set as permanent. Attempting to lock a password or memory bank that is not lockable. Attempting to unlock a password or memory bank that is not un-lockable.
        A lock operation allows a host to execute a tag lock (setting a tag’s access permissions) for all tags of interest.For a single tag, lock the Lock or unlock the data storage area of the Unlock tag. The Select parameter should be set prior to this instruction for selection Locking the Lock operation with the specified tag

Parameters:
password - The access password for the tags.
memSpace - Select the memory space, which should be locked.

    0x00 Kill Password in Reserved memory bank 0x01 Access Password in Reserved memory bank 0x02 EPC memory bank 0x03 TID memory bank 0x04 User memory bank
lockType - Lock actions..Valid values are:

0x00 unlock 0x01 lock 0x02 perma unlock 0x03 perma lock
PC - Response PC buffer 2 bytes
EPC - Response EPC buffer
Returns:
0 if success, other if failed.

  • kill6C

    public int kill6C(byte[] password,
                  byte[] PC,
                  byte[] EPC)
    A kill operation allows a host to kill (i.e. render inoperable) a set of tags of interest. Tag’s whose kill password value is zero do not execute a kill operation; if such a tag receives an 6C Tag Kill it ignores this command and backscatters an error code.
    Parameters:
    password - The kill password for the tags.
    PC - Response PC buffer 2 bytes
    EPC - Response EPC buffer
    Returns:
    0 if success, other number if failed:

      other error -1 password param length errorERROR_CODE_ACCESS_FAIL TAG missing Constants.FAIL_KILL_NO_TAG access password errorConstants.FAIL_KILL_ERROR_CODE_BASE

    public int kill6C(byte[] password,
                  int rfu,
                  byte[] PC,
                  byte[] EPC)

  • NXPReadProtect

    public int NXPReadProtect(int Command,
                          byte[] password,
                          byte[] PC,
                          byte[] EPC)
    After inventory operation, first the host should send a select operation in case there are several tags found, and then perform the write operation and the NXP command set. After a NXP command was performed, the host should re-send a select operation. The correct sequences to operate these commands are shown below:

      Step 1: Perform 6C Tag Inventory Operation Step 2: Pick one tag out of the population found Step 3: Perform 6C Tag Select Operation Step 4: to select or isolate tag Step 5: Perform 6C Tag Write Operation Step 6: to access password location Step 7: Perform 6C Tag NXP Command Set
    The NXP tag which Protect EPC bit in Config-Word has been set to ‘1’ by Change Read Protect Status (set) or Change Config command, its EPC data in the EPC memory will retrun '0' and can't be selected. If the host wants to access the NXP tag which has been read protected, need to enable Quick Aceess Mode and omit select operation to perform tag-protocol operation directly. Performs NXP custom command set for special NXP tags of interest.
    Parameters:
    Command - NXP custom command set:0x00 = ReadProtect 0x01 = Reset ReadProtect.This field set or reset the appropriate Bit of Read protect command. It’s no function for Change Config command.
    password - The access password for the tags.
    PC - Response PC buffer 2 bytes
    EPC - Response EPC buffer
    Returns:
    0 if success, other number if failed:

      other error -1 password param length errorERROR_CODE_ACCESS_FAIL TAG missing Constants.FAIL_NXP_READPROTECT_NO_TAGConstants.FAIL_NXP_RESET_READPROTECT_NO_TAG access password errorConstants.FAIL_ACCESS_PWD_ERROR

  • NXPChangeEAS

    public int NXPChangeEAS(byte[] password,
                        int toggle,
                        byte[] PC,
                        byte[] EPC)
    After a NXP command was performed, the host should re-send a select operation.
    Parameters:
    password - The access password for the tags.
    toggle - The bits of Config-Word which the host wants to toggle PSF (0->1, 1->0) set to 1.

    Example:If the original value of the PSF Alarm bit is 0.

    Set 1 first time will activate the PSF Alarm bit (=1).

    Set 0 again will deactivate the PSF Alarm bit (=0).

    Invalid toggling on indicator or RFU bits of Config-Word are ignored.
    PC - Response PC buffer 2 bytes
    EPC - Response EPC buffer
    Returns:
    0 if success, other number if failed:

      other error -1 password param length errorERROR_CODE_ACCESS_FAIL TAG missing Constants.FAIL_NXP_CHANGE_EAS_NO_TAG access password errorConstants.FAIL_ACCESS_PWD_ERROR

  • NXPTriggerEASAlarm

    public int NXPTriggerEASAlarm(byte[] EASCode)
    Due to the uniqueness of “triggering” EAS Alarm (not set/reset); it is divided from NXP commands. Tags with EAS Alarm is set (refer to NXP Command: Change EAS Status) shall response to EAS Alarm code immediately without any delay caused by Select/Query. 64-bits EAS Alarm code backscattered from tags is expected. The alarm code is fixed numbers but may be various depend on different types of tag in the future. For G2iL+ and G2iM tags, whether EAS Alarm is set can be check by reading 15 th bit of Config Word. It is also known as “PSF Alarm”. Enable EAS Alarm in previous is necessary for triggering EAS Alarm. The host may enable this feature by writing to Config Word directly, or using NXP commands.
      Step 1:Power on module and set antenna power Step 2:Send command to trigger EAS Alarm
    Parameters:
    EASCode - Response EAS Code buffer.64-bits EAS Code backscattered from tags.EAS Code is fixed hex number: 690A EC7C D215 D8F9 for G2iL+,G2iM and G2X series. This field reports received EAS Code or all zero value depends on different value of Status field:

    PSF = 1 EAS Code is received and considered valid. Received EAS Code is replied.
    • PSF = 0 Or Other Status.No EAS Code is received
    Returns:
    Byte number of response data length.return -1 if no EAS Code is received.

    public boolean open()
    Init the UHF module.
    Returns:
    true if success, false if failed.

    public boolean close()
    release UHF hardware device and power off.
    Returns:
    true if success, false if failed.

    Parameters:
    data -
    Returns:
    Checksum

  • Bytes2HexString

    protected static java.lang.String Bytes2HexString(byte[] b,
                                                  int size)
    Controls the power state of RFID module’s physical antenna port with the first frequency of channel list. The power state of the physical antenna port. 0x00 = power off 0xFF = power on Default value is 0x00 (power off).
